SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

lotus.domino
Interface International

All Superinterfaces:
Base
public interface International
extends Base

Represents the international settings in the operating environment, for example, the Regional Settings in the Windows Control Panel. When settings change in the operating environment, Notes recognizes the new settings immediately. For remote (IIOP) operations, these settings represent the session's server.

Containment

Contained by: Session

Access

Access an International object for the current session through getInternational in Session.

See Also

Example
Java Classes A-Z
Accessing international settings
Running a Java program

getParent

Session getParent()
                  throws NotesException
Read-only. The Notes session that contains an International object.

See Also

Example

Throws:
NotesException

getTimeZone

int getTimeZone()
                throws NotesException
Read-only. An integer representing the time zone. In many cases, but not all, this integer indicates the number of hours that must be added to the time to get Greenwich Mean Time. May be positive or negative.

Throws:
NotesException

isDST

boolean isDST()
              throws NotesException
Read-only. Indicates whether the time format reflects daylight savings time.

Legal values

  • true if the time format reflects daylight savings time
  • false if the time format does not reflect daylight savings time

See Also

isCurrencySuffix

boolean isCurrencySuffix()
                         throws NotesException
Read-only. Indicates whether the currency symbol follows the number in the currency format.

Legal values

  • true if the currency symbol follows the number
  • false if the currency symbol precedes the number

See Also

Accessing international settings

Throws:
NotesException

isCurrencySpace

boolean isCurrencySpace()
                        throws NotesException
Read-only. Indicates whether the currency format has a space between the currency symbol and the number.

Legal values

  • true if the currency format has a space between the currency symbol and the number
  • false if the currency format does not have a space between the currency symbol and the number

Usage

Under UNIX, this property is derived from the language installed on the machine as indicated by the LANG environment variable.

See Also

Accessing international settings

Throws:
NotesException

isCurrencyZero

boolean isCurrencyZero()
                       throws NotesException
Read-only. Indicates whether fractions have a zero before the decimal point in number format.

Legal values

  • true if fractions have a zero before the decimal point
  • false if fractions do not have a zero before the decimal point

Usage

Under UNIX, this property is meaningless.

See Also

Accessing international settings

NotesException

recycle

void recycle(java.util.Vector arg1)
             throws NotesException
The recycle method unconditionally destroys an object and returns its memory to the system.

All lotus.domino classes contain the following methods:

public void recycle()
public void recycle(java.util.Vector objects)

In the latter method, the vector contains the Domino Objects to be recycled. This method effectively batches recycle operations and is especially efficient for remote (IIOP) calls.

Java has no knowlege of the heavyweight back-end Domino Objects, only the lightweight Java objects representing them. Garbage collection has no effect on Domino Objects unless you first explicitly recycle them.

If you appear to have memory problems, try recycle but adhere to the following guidelines:

  • Recycle an object only if it is no longer needed.
  • Recycle an object in the same thread in which it is created.
  • Recycling a parent recycles all the children.
  • In Session, call recycle() only after all other threads exit.
  • Where NotesThread.sinitThread() and NotesThread.stermThread() are used, call recycle() before stermThread.

Loops enumerating documents or items are good candidates for recycling.

In a remote (IIOP) environment, recycle releases resources on the server. Although a client-side cache exists, the Java object can no longer communicate with its remote counterpart.

In a remote (IIOP) environment, recycle can be called from any thread on any object.

If you create more than one object to represent the same Domino element, recycling one recycles all. For example:

View v1 = db.getView("All");
View v2 = db.getView("All");
v1.recycle(); // also recycles v2

Results are undefined if you attempt to use a recycled object. No error is guaranteed.

See Also

Supporting components

Specified by:
recycle in interface Base
Throws:
NotesException
